chapter.title: User Documentation
chapter.para: This chapter deals with writing user documentation, like user guides. It gives pointers, and ideas on how it can be done, and shows how the CDK documentation is written.

section.title: jEdit: a XML aware editor
section.para: No, jEdit is not the only XML aware editor, and you do not need to use it; use any editor you like. It is just mentioned here to show the power of an XML aware editor. Emacs can do similar things.

What has an XML aware editor to offer over other editors? jEdit is a text editor, not a wysiwyg editor, so has some downside for Word users. But, for people used to LaTeX or HTML source code, jEdit (using a few plugins) offers much functionality like tag completion, validation and a structure browser. And regular expression searches, XPath searching if you like, XML indentation, and maybe more. But this is what I mostly use. Moreover, jEdit is written in Java (which you already have installed, because you need it for CDK anyway, and thus runs on your favorite platform. And, last but not least, it's a great Java source code editor too.
So, where do I go to download jEdit? jEdit's download site has binary and installers for most common platforms. When this section was written, version 4.1 was the stable release.

Then remains the question on plugins. jEdit has a very powerful plugin platform (yes, much better than CDK's...). Plugins can be installed directly form the internet from within jEdit using an internet connection. A separate website, http://plugins.jedit.org/ is home to those plugins, and many are available. The XML specific plugins which I have installed are: XML, XmlIndenter and SideKick. The first contains the tag completion, and tag insertion (based on DTD or XML Schema), and the second... well, that must be clear. The last plugin offers a Structure Browser which shows the XML structure in tree format. Very useful.

section.title: CDK's XML URL module thingy
section.para: This XML entity module can be included in your XML file, and then offers entities (kind of macro's) that provide a DocBook ulink element pointing to the JavaDoc documentation of the CDK classes on the CDK website.

For example, the module provides the org.Atom entity of which the value is <ulink url="http://cdk.sf.net/api/org/openscience/cdk/Atom.html">Atom</ulink>. The classes.mod file is generated using a JavaDoc doclet, in the cdk/doc/javadoc directory.

section.title: CDK Programming Tutorial
section.para: There is a sort of CDK Programming Tutorial online. It is written in DocBook XML 4.1.2 (like most of our documentation).

section.title: Example: JChemPaint User Guide
section.para: An example of user documentation is the User Guide of JChemPaint. Like the CDK documentation, it is written in DocBook XML. It is converted into HTML so that it can be displayed from within the JChemPaint program using Java's standard HTML viewer. Additionally, the DocBook source is included in the website source which is written in the Website DTD, written by Norman Walsh, who is also one of the main developers of DocBook XML. The Website DTD was designed, and extends, the DocBook DTD, and the result is a very nicely integrated user guide pages.
